29.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain, coming to
you this week from Germany.

33.text:
We are in Scotland looking at one of the wonders
of the natural world: the grey geese - and

40.text:
First, I am outside Berlin with hunters from
all over the world, and we are shooting driven

47.text:
The mouflon is one of the most popular quarry
animals in Europe. It was once an important

52.text:
sporting quarry for British big game hunters.
My great-grandfather took my great-grandmother

58.text:
mouflon shooting in Sardinia for their honeymoon
- they knew how to give a girl a good time

64.text:
Well, we start the trip at an old military
range outside Berlin where Zeiss has brought

69.text:
nearly 100 gun shop owners from around the
world from as far away as Australia, United

75.text:
States, France, Scandinavia, Austria, not
Libya, and they are going to shoot a variety

78.text:
of different targets beginning with something
you are more likely to see at a children's

90.text:
The range day is a chance for Zeiss to show
off its range of riflescopes; it gives the

94.text:
local forestry department a strong sense of
relief that we can shoot straight; and it

98.text:
allows us to find out which is the top shooting
nation.

103.text:
David Traill runs the gun and fishing tackle
shop Grahams of Inverness.

106.text: Have you done boar shooting before?

109.text:
Never - never shot anything - never anything
driven.

113.text:
My entire shooting experience is either wing
shooting or just stalking - general British

118.text:
stalking. This is entirely new and it's not
particularly easy either.

122.text:
Out of all the targets you tried today what
was the really tricky one?

129.text:
I think anything when you are standing completely
unsupported because it goes against all - you

135.text:
know - we would only take that type of shot
in Scotland after a wounded animal for example.

143.text:
You wouldn't purposefully go and stand up
like a cowboy and shoot things. So anything

147.text: where I was doing that I found quite challenging.

151.text:
A lot of people found the prone shot on the
fox quite difficult.

155.text:
Yeah - that was actually. It's interesting
to come and see the way these guys shoot because

161.text:
they are using skills that we have maybe written
out of our shooting vocabulary, because we

167.text:
have bipods, and because we shoot from - in
woodland shooting for example - shooting from

174.text:
These guys that are doing this all the time,
their shooting - you know - is better honed

183.text:
You come to places like Germany and these
facilities are dotted all over the country.

187.text:
It just gives you an indication of the entirely
different culture of shooting that they have

194.text:
It's fascinating to come and be a part of
it.

196.text:
We shoot boar running right to left, as well
as static fox, roe deer targets and balloons.

201.text:
The one everyone likes best is the big male
wild boar, the 'keiler' coming at you.

207.text:
The wild boar comes closer on you and you
have three shots which you have to place on

214.text: the wild boar until the light goes up.

217.text:
Then we try a variation: start with your cartridge
clip on the table and your hands in your pockets.

230.text:
We found, however, that the running targets
are easier than you might think. The target

234.text:
that produces the biggest problem for shooters
is the prone shot at the fox.

239.text:
And now, the winner of Most Accurate Nation:
the top three shots are, in reverse order,

248.text:
Of course, I heard that the British shot not
so good.

254.text: You can't shoot. You can't shoot for xxxx.

257.text:
I heard - have you heard that all the British
are actually going to go with the dogs today?

263.text: They are beaters? And now this is what I mean.

266.text: The British Army is here especially for you.

271.text: Team GB has some catching up to do.

274.text:
We are shooting on a huge military training
area outside Berlin. Zeiss is renting it from

279.text:
the German government. British breasts swell
with pride: a regiment of our engineers are

285.text:
training on one part of the area today. We
hope they will push game over to our part.

291.text:
And the German capital: not far away and looks
undefended. Mrs Merkel would be surprised.

298.text:
Back to the sheep. Many British shooters do
not like the idea of shooting running animals.

303.text:
It might be Hallowe'en but aiming at big game
on the hoof is not the horror story that they

310.text:
For one thing, a day in a 10,000-acre forest
with ninety dodgy foreigners armed with rifles

315.text:
needs meticulous planning and a full morning's
worth of lessons about what you can and cannot

321.text:
Be aware don't shoot a running stag. Wait
until he stands to be very sure there is only

330.text: Find out what happens later in the programme.

332.text:
Now from the dark forests of Germany to David
on the Fieldsports Channel news stump.

349.text:
As the foxhunting season gets underway, opening
meets across the country attract record numbers

355.text:
of supporters. Hunts maintain they keep to
the letter of the law, and figures released

359.text:
by the Ministry of Justice show that there
was only one conviction for hunting last year

364.text:
by an individual connected with a registered
hunt. Ninety-seven per cent of convictions

368.text:
since the Hunting Act came into force relate
to poaching, including at least seven people

373.text: who have been convicted of hunting rats.

377.text:
Talking of poachers, the West Country's red
stags are in the crosshairs of public attention

383.text:
Illegal shooters on Exmoor shot a 19-point
stag dubbed the Goodleigh Giant. This beats

389.text:
the medium-sized Exmoor Emperor by five points.
They wounded it, hitting it two or three times

394.text:
in the back and it later died. Its carcase
was found by a local vet. Shooting enthusiasts

400.text: immediately condemned the actions of the poachers.

403.text:
Now, bad news for pheasant fanciers: the World
Pheasant Association, which is supported by

409.text:
shooting interests, reports that that the
Edwards' pheasant may be extinct in the wild.

415.text:
The species is only found in the lowland forests
of central Vietnam, where habitat loss has

420.text:
had a heavy impact. Matthew Grainger of the
WPA explains why the bird has gone.

427.text:
It's a lowland forest specialist and a lot
of the lowland forest in Vietnam has been

436.text:
destroyed. It has been converted to agriculture,
for mainly rice paddies.

439.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
news: stalking the stories, fishing for facts.

452.text:
The morning of the hunt dawns and some of
the shooters here do not know what to expect.

460.text:
Everyone knows that hunting practices vary
widely around the world.

464.text:
Jim McClain has a gunshop in the Deep South
of the United States. Surely he has been on

470.text: a day as big as this?

472.text:
Would you do a alligator hunt like this? Would
you have as many people out for that sort

476.text: Wear a flak vest and be very careful.

478.text:
Now, before you are tempted to go and shoot
some Suffolks in a field, know that mouflon

483.text:
have more in common with gazelle than the
average lamb chop. With a top speed of 40

488.text: miles an hour, they are as fast as a pheasant.

492.text:
Mark Karn, who runs Zeiss Sports Optics in
the UK is on a stand out in the open. He could

498.text:
be taking some long shots on any game that
comes out. Guns start booming around us, but

504.text:
there is nothing heading our way. Big-bag
driven pheasant this isn't.

510.text:
We've heard some going off over there. They've
certainly driven something out. But at the

530.text:
There's a mouflon that's just come out of
there - but unsuccessful. It's the first thing

543.text:
we've seen all morning. Ah - yeah. But we'll
see what we get now. It's on the move and

556.text:
we should have still got. We should have still
got it.

563.text:
No. You tell that to the poor guy up there
- still isn't shooting.

568.text:
As the clock strikes one, Mark unloads and
climbs down. He wants to make sure he definitely

576.text:
He did miss - there is no sign of blood. As
we wait for the Land Rover, three red deer

582.text:
come trotting out of the wood to add insult
to the lack of injury Mark has inflicted.

587.text: They see us and leg it.

590.text:
In the Land Rover trailer are a whole flock
of mouflon. Using a double-barrelled over-and-under,

596.text:
one of the guns shot five of them in under
a minute. Two of the sheep have good heads,

601.text:
which will cost that gun thousands of Euros
in trophy fees. Our driver thinks that's hilarious.

607.text:
Is that what he spent? He spent 4,000 Euros
in five shots?

614.text: In one minute! In one minute! Congratulations!

616.text: And this is all going to go to Greece.

620.text: All the money goes to Greece.

622.text:
I have shot - some years before a deer - a
big deer. And I have thought now I must take

632.text: my Harley Davidson [laughs] and change it.

639.text:
So which of the guns was it? It could be only
the Norwegian, Sturla.

644.text: You heard me? Did you hear myů?

647.text: I have not heard. What happened?

652.text:
I think I shot four small foxes or something.
Five? Or mouflon - I don't know.

656.text: Are you proud of what you have done?

659.text:
No actually. Now actually I am a little bit
depressed because - you know how it is - I

664.text:
have to make the speech tonight again. As
normal. So I'm really bored about thinking

670.text: of the hunt. Tomorrow I will go with the beaters.

674.text:
This is an ordinary day's hunting for a Norwegian,
but what do Australians thing about it?

678.text:
It's a very disciplined approach to hunting
they have.

689.text: Taken seriously. It's good to see.

693.text:
And good hunting and management practices
are very good as well.

703.text:
More sheep in a minute. Next we a have a new
series. The director of shooting at the Countryside

709.text:
Alliance, David Taylor, is off to see the
great wildlife events of Great Britain, and

713.text:
find out how shooting sports keeps them happening.
It's Taylor's Travels.

728.text:
That's an awful lot of swans. I'm in Easter
Ross, east of Inverness, next stop Norway.

733.text:
This place is an absolute haven for wildlife.
This morning I went out with a local goose

738.text:
If you want to turn a large skein of geese
and bring them over guns, you need to know

749.text:
Just blow it very gently. You blow it too
hard and it makes a distress call and they

755.text: Or if you've pinks coming in, your sound isů

756.text: ůmore a sort of chatty call.

757.text:
And what is a distress call - if you have
heard them making it?

765.text:
The sea's just over on the other side I believe.
You've got the wind coming in to us this way,

776.text:
so we're laying the decoys out head to wind
that way.

781.text:
Because he is a farmer, James is well-placed
to watch the geese here. He observes to conserve

786.text: and has strict rules for his shooters.

788.text:
There's geese coming in here. I mean, farming
practices have changed. Twenty years ago there

793.text:
was a lot of spring barley grown here. Now
there's a lot of oilseed rape, winter wheat,

797.text:
winter oats. There's less stubbles to go on
but we've still got a fair number in. Twenty

803.text:
years ago, we may have had 40,000 on the loch.
Now it's maybe 10,000 or 15,000. It varies

809.text:
You're very careful about bags and things
like that.

812.text:
We shoot a brace per gun and we stop. It's
as simple as that.

815.text:
A lot of people go a lot further than that,
don't they? Not necessarily a good thing.

831.text:
That's their choice, but I don't approve of
it.

839.text:
much of a problem for the farmers until the
spring drillings. But for local tourism during

840.text:
the shooting season, they can be a real boon.
Many people travel much further than the birds

850.text:
There's something wild and natural about geese
which is a huge attraction, especially for

855.text:
some of the French people. And it's the beauty
and the unspoilt areas they get to shoot in.

864.text:
They're well away from industrial areas, and
all the rest of it, and it's just a very beautiful

870.text: You had a good morning, didn't you?

873.text:
And that was all part of the magic? Seeing
those geese?

876.text:
Yeah - it's seeing the volume of geese and
the fact you get your shot. You've always

881.text:
got a good chance of getting a shot. No guarantees.
And - you know - have your few and then leave

887.text: them alone. They are there for again.

892.text: Pretty much so - yes - pretty much so.

894.text:
Back at the field it has been an hour and
not much has come over. Then our luck changes.

899.text:
Just as we begin packing up, the geese and
the hooper swans start moving.

903.text:
Very exciting. We've had quite a few flying
over. Some of them very high. Quite a few

906.text:
of them in the field behind us. Lots of swans
as well. Lots of action but no shooting. A

913.text:
couple of shots down over there. But not much
over here.

917.text:
When it begins to quieten down, James drives
up and suggests we back go to Loch Eye where

923.text:
At the loch, we see geese lift from surrounding
stubble. All that goes over us is a wedge

928.text: of swans. I prefer a 'pageant' of swans.

930.text:
It's been an amazing morning. It seems like
a long way away from the dry the corridors

935.text:
of Westminster where I spend my time as the
director of shooting for the Countryside Alliance

939.text:
trying to convince MPs that lead isn't the
devil's work. Goose shooting is an incredibly

945.text:
accessible sport and every shooter should
try it. For more information on Lachie's guiding

951.text:
services, email him at ls@highlandsporting.com.
For more information on the Countryside Alliance's

957.text: shooting campaign, visit us at www.countryside-alliance.org.uk.

963.text:
Well it's the start of day two and I won't
be needing these. I am abandoning my British

970.text:
friends today and joining a German to see
how they do driven game.

975.text:
Up he goes on to his stand, sits, waits, waits
and waits. German or not, we draw another

983.text:
blank - the distant booms indicate this is
a bigger day. Not for us, but at least Stefan

992.text:
This is a gun that was manufactured in Ferlach,
one of the most famous places where you find

1003.text:
gun-smiths in Austria. You have two barrels,
over-and-under. Calibre is 9.3x74R. It's a

1013.text:
very lightweight, very slim and very beautiful
little gun. As you can see, lots of the engravings,

1023.text:
locking system similar to the ones from shotguns.
But it's a double action over-and-under rifle.

1034.text:
David Traill has more luck. So what does he
think of shooting moving game?

1041.text:
Reticent - just - but again, I think because
I don't have a skill-set which enables me

1048.text:
to be confident in doing it. But he wasn't
far away. He was pausing, presented his neck

1055.text:
quite nicely, bad luck for him, good luck
for me, everything worked out very well. That

1062.text:
was OK but had he been a bigger boy and moving
at speed with a group, would I have felt so

1071.text:
One of the joys of this hunt is meeting so
many nationalities - not just Scottish - and

1077.text: talking to them about sport in their countries.

1079.text:
I want to talk to you particularly because
you're from Iceland and you have all our geese.

1085.text:
Yes - we keep them from the spring till the
autumn, and we feed them carefully, shoot

1089.text: a few of them and send them back to you.

1091.text:
You don't - you shoot them to pieces - we
know you do.

1093.text:
No no - we don't shoot so many. It's about
3,000 hunters who go out and totally we shoot

1098.text:
something like 40,000 geese in Iceland. So
you still have about 150,000 left.

1104.text:
So, do you get cross with the British for
shooting all your geese coming back?

1109.text:
No no - the population of geese is growing
every year. The number of hunters is also

1114.text:
growing but much more slowly. So we cannot
see any problem. We can mix this population

1122.text:
And then there are the Americans, and one
of them is a TV star.

1125.text:
You hunt all over the world for your TV show,
Headhunter Chronicles. What was this outing

1132.text:
I enjoy this type of hunting just because
it's a tradition, so you get to come to Europe

1137.text:
- come to Germany and stuff like that - you
see the hunting here that's probably thousands

1143.text:
of years old. We have a hunting heritage in
the US - it's only a few hundred years old.

1147.text:
So, just really neat to see the culture, see
the people and, bottom line, it's a tradition

1153.text:
Do you think this kind of thing will be a
hit on your TV show?

1155.text:
Yeah - I think people are definitely interested
in watching that kind of stuff.

1158.text: You shot one yesterday. What was that like?

1160.text:
Yeah - it was fun. We ended up shooting three
different mouflon - one ram and - actually

1164.text:
two rams and one female - and at different
ranges, and some of them were driven and some

1169.text:
stopped. So, it makes it difficult, you know.
The running ones - you can't really judge

1173.text:
them. It's definitely a fun hunt. And you
get to see the dogs and stuff like that.

1178.text:
You are an American TV personality, therefore
you must give us a plug for your show. What

1183.text: is it and when is it on?

1185.text:
We're on the Pursuit Channel, every Friday
night at 8 o'clock, and it's Headhunter Chronicles.

1190.text:
The final tally is 80 head of game over two
days and nothing wounded that wasn't followed,

1199.text:
British shoot owners watching this may wonder
at how Zeiss arranged for nearly 100 shooters

1204.text:
and their rifles to come here. Ralph Nebe
is our host and he explains.

1208.text:
So you have to start six months in advance
to find the right location. You have to start

1215.text:
six months in advance to organise the hunting
licence. That's the most difficult thing,

1221.text:
because in Germany it's quite difficult to
get the hunting licence, and there we have

1224.text:
a co-operation with the forest and hunting
department. They did a very good job.

1229.text:
Germany takes the safety side of it very,
very seriously indeed. That seemed to be most

1235.text:
impressive because, in the UK, we turn up
with some guns, we are put out on our pegs,

1241.text:
we are told not to shoot each other. But it's
more than that in Germany, isn't it?

1244.text:
It is. It is. Because the way we do our driven
hunt, we have also dogs and drivers in the

1252.text:
hunt, sometimes also people with a rifle,
and the hunters are positioned on high seats.

1258.text:
And you have plenty of game - I think we have
counted in these two days 120 shots - so safety

1266.text:
is very, very important. And the ground sometimes
is very hard. You have stony ground. Then

1271.text:
it could easily happen that the bullet drops
off and hits somebody.

1274.text:
What benefit is this, apart from giving the
gunshop owners a good time?

1275.text:
So, the benefit for us: the dealers we invited,
these are our best dealers worldwide. And

1282.text:
it's a kind of incentive to say thank you
to them, and also to share a joint passion

1292.text:
for hunting, and to build a network - a very
strong network. You know in our industry,

1298.text:
it's a very small industry. Relationship is
everything, and this close relationship with

1305.text:
these dealers, that will strengthen our business,
no doubt. And you see the event was very,

1309.text:
very successful. Everybody was happy. And
I promise you they will never forget. Their

1314.text:
shoulder mount hanging on the wall - they
will always remember that event.

1317.text: Were they all using Zeiss scopes?

1321.text: At least I didn't see body who did not.

1328.text:
Well, this has been Fieldsports Britain, sorting
out the sheep from the chaff, as we do every

1334.text:
week. We're back next week and if you haven't
done so already and you are watching us on

1339.text:
YouTube, please click the Ĺsubscribe' button,
which is just out there somewhere. Or go to

1353.text:
